name: Basic Cooked Rice
history: Rice is a staple food in many cultures around the world. Its cultivation dates back thousands of years in multiple regions, including Asia, Africa, and the Americas.
description: A simple and foundational recipe for cooking plain rice, which can be a base for various dishes or served as a side. It involves boiling rice in water until tender and fluffy.

equipment.name: strainer
equipment.description: For rinsing the rice before cooking.

instructions.title: Rinse the Rice
instructions.description: Rinse the rice under cold water using a strainer until the water runs clear. This removes excess starch and prevents the rice from becoming sticky.

instructions.title: Cook the Rice
instructions.description: In a saucepan, combine the rinsed rice, water, and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat.

instructions.title: Simmer the Rice
instructions.description: Once boiling, reduce the heat to low, cover the saucepan with a lid, and let the rice simmer for about 15 minutes, or until all the water is absorbed and the rice is tender.

instructions.title: Rest and Fluff
instructions.description: Remove the saucepan from heat and let it sit, covered, for 5 minutes. Then, fluff the rice with a fork to separate the grains.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the rice as a base for other dishes or as a side. It can be paired with a variety of sauces, vegetables, or proteins.

tips: For extra flavor, cook the rice in broth instead of water or add herbs and spices.
Leftover rice can be refrigerated and used in stir-fries or as a quick side dish.
variations: Brown Rice: Use brown rice instead of white, but increase cooking time as needed.

storage.shelfLife: Refrigerate cooked rice in an airtight container and use within 3-4 days.
storage.instructions: Cool the rice quickly and refrigerate; reheat thoroughly before serving.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in a microwave or on the stove with a splash of water to add moisture back into the rice.
presentationTips: Serve in a bowl or on a plate as a base for curries, stews, or stir-fries.
Garnish with chopped herbs for a fresh touch.
